question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
As a researcher in the field of molecular biology with a focus on signaling pathways, I am fascinated by how intracellular communication is orchestrated through the phosphorylation of proteins. My motivation for this experiment stems from a desire to understand these complex biochemical processes more deeply, specifically within the context of neurodegenerative diseases and muscle disorders. Hence, the purpose of this experiment is to utilize the Bio-Plex phosphoprotein assay to simultaneously measure the levels of phosphorylated proteins in the spinal cords and skeletal muscles of mice. This will allow me to identify changes in these phosphoproteins that may be linked to pathological states, potentially shedding light on novel therapeutic targets or biomarkers of disease progression.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Bio-Plex ProTM Cell Signaling Assay kit (Bio-Rad Laboratories) 
2. DCTM Protein Assay

3. Tissue grinder
4. Scissors
5. Freezer
6. Sonicater
7. Aluminum foil 
8. Eppendorf Tubes Centrifuge
9. Plate reader for measuring protein concentration
10. Magnetic washer
11. Plate shaker
12. LuminexR 200 xPONETR 3.1 system (Merck Millipore)
answer:
1. Cut the tissue into small pieces (~3x3 mm) in a 1.5 ml tissue grinder
2. Add 10 times volume of cell lysis buffer and grind the tissue on ice using 20 strokes
3. Freeze samples at -80℃.
4. Thaw the sample and sonicate on ice (1 min)
5. Centrifuge at 15000xg for 10 min at 4℃
6. Collect the supernatant
7. Measure the protein concentration using DCTM Protein Assay and a plate reader
8. Adjust the concentration of protein to 600µg/ml with cell lysis buffer
9. Freeze samples at -80℃
10. Thaw sample lysates and keep on ice
11. Reconstitute lyophilized cell lysate control with 250 µl of dH2O, vortex for 5 sec to mix and incubate at room temperature for 20 min
12. Centrifuge all samples and lysate controls at 15000xg for 10 min at 4℃
13. Vortex the 20x coupled beads at mid speed for 30 sec and carefully open the cap
14. Dilute coupled beads to 1x with wash buffer, vortex, protect from light with aluminum foil. For the assay in 96wells, mix 288 µl of 20x beads with 5472 µl of wash buffer.
15. Vortex the 1xbeads for 15 sec at medium speed and transfer 50 µl to each well of the assay plate
16. Wash the plate two times with 200 µl wash buffer using magnetic washer
17. Transfer 50 µl of each sample and Bio-Rad cell lysate control to the appropriate wells of the plate. Use detection antibody diluent as the blank.
18. Cover the plate with a new sheet of sealing tape and incubate in the dark for 15-18 hr at room temperature with shaking. Shake at 900-1100 rpm for 30 sec and turn down to 300-450 rpm.
19. Start up, warm up, and calibrate LuminexR 200 xPONETR 3.1 system
20. Bring all buffers and diluents to room temperature
21. Vortex the 20x detection antibodies for 15-20 sec at medium speed
22. Dilute detection antibodies to 1x with detection antibody diluent. For 96wells, mix 150 µl of 20x detection antibodies with 2850 µl of detection antibody diluent.
23. Slowly remove and discard the sealing tape of the assay plate
24. Wash the plate three times with 200 µl wash buffer using magnetic washer
25. Vortex the 1x detection antibodies and transfer 25 µl to each well of the assay plate
26. Cover the plate with a new sheet of sealing tape and incubate in the dark for 30 min at room temperature with shaking. Shake at 900-1100 rpm for 30 sec and turn down to 300-450 rpm.
27. Vortex the 100x Sreptavidin-PE (SA-PE) for 5 sec at medium speed
28. Dilute SA-PE to 1x with detection antibody diluent. For the assay in 96wells, mix 150 µl of 20x detection antibodies with 2850 µl of detection antibody diluent.
29. Slowly remove and discard the sealing tape of the assay plate
30. Wash the plate three times with 200 µl wash buffer using magnetic washer
31. Vortex the 1x SA-PE and transfer 50 µl to each well of the assay plate
32. Cover the plate with a new sheet of sealing tape and incubate in the dark for 10 min at room temperature with shaking. Shake at 900-1100 rpm for 30 sec and turn down to 300-450 rpm.
33. Slowly remove and discard the sealing tape of the assay plate
34. Wash the plate three times with 200 µl wash buffer using magnetic washer
35. To resuspend beads for plate reading, add 125 µl resuspension buffer to each well. Cover the plate with a new sheet of sealing tape and shake at 900-1100 rpm for 30 sec.
36. Slowly remove the sealing tape and place the plate on the reader

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I wanted to develop and evaluate the accuracy of a machine learning model, specifically DeepLabCut, for real-time tracking in behavioral experiments. My motivation stemmed from the need to improve the precision of tracking animal movements in studies, where traditional methods might fail due to rapid, complex behaviors or challenging recording conditions. The purpose of the experiment was twofold: firstly, to assess the root mean square error (RMSE) of the DeepLabCut models as a measure of tracking accuracy, and secondly, to evaluate the performance of a closed-loop system by analyzing the rates of false negatives and false positives. This would enable me to fine-tune the model and the system for better real-time response in behavioral experiments, ultimately enhancing the quality and reliability of behavioral data analysis.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Agar
2. Cornmeal
3. Yeast
4. Glucose
5. Propionic acid
6. 10% Methyl p-hydroxybenzoate in 70% EtOH
7. dH2O
8. Python/Anaconda
9. Custom-script for Bonsai
10. Custom Arduino sketch
11. PC equipped with NVIDIA GPU
12. Google Colaboratory
13. Aluminum plate with anodic oxide coating
14. LED lights
answer:
1. Set up the fly crosses. Introduce parental flies (4–5 *piezo-GAL4* males and *UAS-GtACR1* virgin females) into vials containing fly media.
2. Transfer parental flies (F0 fly) to fresh vials every 5 days.
3. Collect F1 males of the desired genotypes.
4. Prepare plastic tubes containing ∼150 μL of fly food.
5. For the experimental group, add 2 μL of ATR, 25 mg/mL dissolved in 99.5% EtOH on the food surface. For the control group, add 2 μL of 99.5% EtOH on the food surface instead of ATR.
6. Transfer males to a plastic tube containing fly food with the surface covered with ATR (or EtOH) 24–36 h before the experiment.
7. Keep the male flies on prepared food for 24–36 h in the dark before being used for the assays.
8. Put a fixed female at the center of a courtship chamber.
9. Position the green laser using a manipulator to adjust the focusing area to the female genitalia.
10. Introduce a male fly into the chamber without anesthesia.
11. Enclose them with a cover glass.
12. Run a custom Bonsai script and take movies.
13. Turn on the two calibration LEDs at the beginning of each recording to calibrate the start timing of movies recorded by each camera.
14. Blink the two calibration LEDs three times so that LED lights appear on two cameras (Camera-A and Camera-B) at the beginning of each movie file.
15. Align the onsets of movies based on the calibration LED of each movie.
16. Stop the Bonsai program after ∼1 h or copulation has finished.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I've noticed that soybean, a crucial global crop, is severely affected by the Asian Soybean Rust (ASR) disease caused by *Phakopsora pachyrhizi*. My motivation is to understand how this fungus infects soybean plants and to test the effectiveness of fungicides in controlling this disease. The purpose of my experiment is to use a detached-leaf assay to simulate *P. pachyrhizi* infections on soybean leaves in a controlled environment. I aim to observe and classify the development of lesions and pustules over a 12-day period and estimate the density of uredospores to gauge infection severity. This research could offer valuable insights into managing ASR in soybean crops and further our knowledge of plant-pathogen interactions.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
Materials and Reagents

1. Soybean transgenic and non-transgenic plants of similar age
2. Leaves infected with *Phakopsora pachyrhizi* uredospores
3. Tween 20 (Labsynth)
4. Uredospore suspension

Equipment

1. Petri dish (Ø 9 cm)
2. Hand sprayer that can be adjusted for spraying 1 ml volume
3. Plant culture room
4. Growth chamber
5. Stereomicroscope
6. Laminar flow sterile cabinet
7. Neubauer chamber
answer:
1. Leaves infected with *Phakopsora pachyrhizi* uredospores were randomly sampled in the field. Alternatively, uredospores of a determined isolate were propagated on plants under greenhouse conditions. Immediately after sampling, leaves were stored in a dry plastic or paper bag at room temperature up to four days. However, better results are expected from material recently collected or stored under refrigeration.  
2. In the laboratory, uredospores were tapped off of the leaves into a suitable dry tube using a paint-brush, as shown in Video 2. This step should be done a short time before inoculation, that means, the time necessary to carry out 3-5 steps. The amount of uredospores depends on the amount of leaves that will be included in the experiment.  
3. Fifty ml uredospore suspension was prepared using sterile distilled water, 1 drop of Tween 20 and uredospores to a final concentration of 1 x 105 spores/ml. The concentration of uredospores was estimated using a Neubauer chamber. The Tween 20 was added using a pipette, as shown in Video 3. Fifty ml solution can be used to infect approximately 50 leaves.
4. Soybean transgenic and non-transgenic plants were cultivated in a plant culture room at 26 Â± 1 Â°C with a 16/8 h light/dark cycle at a light intensity of 22.5 ÂµE/m2/s. Fully expanded trifoliate leaves with similar size and position were collected from plants of the same age. The newest fully expanded leaf of 2-month-old plants (V5 or V6 stages) was preferentially used, but plants in other growth stages may be also used.
5. From this step forward, the material was aseptically manipulated in a laminar flow cabinet. The leaves were rinsed (quick submersion) in sterile distilled water and rapidly dried on sterile filter paper. Each leaflet was cut into 5 cm x 5 cm pieces and individually placed with the abaxial side upwards in a sterile Petri dish (Ø 9 cm) containing filter paper saturated with distilled water to maintain high humidity.
6. Each leaf piece was inoculated by spraying 1 ml of the uredospore suspension (105 spores/ml). The uredospore suspension was mixed immediately before each inoculation. A distance of 10 cm was maintained between the hand sprayer and the leaf piece.
7. The Petri dishes were incubated in a growth chamber at 20 Â°C with a 12/12 h light/dark cycle for 12 days.
8. The material was visually evaluated for the presence of lesions and pustules every 2 days during the incubation period.
9. After 12 days of incubation, leaves showing signals of other diseases or rotting were eliminated. The remaining material was visually classified according to the lesion type (immune, reddish brown or tan) present on the abaxial side of the leaf. Additionally, the number of lesions, the number of lesions with pustules, the number of pustules per lesion, the total number of pustules and the total number of opened pustules present on each leaf piece was recorded under a stereomicroscope. Finally, two infected areas of 1 cm x 1 cm were determined in each leaf piece and cut off. Each 1 cm2 piece was placed in a microtube containing 500 Âµl water and vortexed vigorously for 1 min. The mean number of uredospores per cm2 was estimated under a stereomicroscope using a Neubauer chamber.
10. Results obtained from each leaf piece were considered replicates. Tree leaf pieces from the same plant and at least two plants from each transgenic event were used.
11. Non-transformed plants of the same genetic background were used as a control. Ideally, a susceptible and a partially resistant variety should be used as positive and negative controls of the experimental conditions.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I've been facing significant challenges in my genetic studies due to the high variance in functional and phenotypic studies caused by genetic and epigenetic differences in cell populations. This variance often leads to irreproducible results, severely impacting biomedical research's reliability and progress. To address this issue, my goal was to create a comprehensive resource that could unambiguously link genes to phenotypes. Therefore, I set out to develop a resource of murine embryonic stem cell (ESC) clones with targeted, barcoded mutations. These clones are designed as conditional knockouts to allow for the precise control of mutation induction and reversal, aiming to improve reproducibility and enable robust, comprehensive interrogation of the genome. My purpose is to facilitate rigorous genetic studies by providing the scientific community access to the largest homozygous mutant ES library and supporting protocols for its use.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Cell lines
2. Oligonucleotide sequences
3. Standard serum-LIF
4. 2i culture condition
5. Sterile hood
6. Centrifuge
7. Microscope
8. Cell culture dishes
9. Pipettes
10. Media
11. PCR machines
answer:
1. Register at www.haplobank.at to order Haplobank cell lines.
2. Download the supplementary file "haplobank booklet" for detailed protocols concerning the use of the clone collection.
3. After receiving the shipment, recover cells from thawing, which typically takes 2 days.
4. Study phenotypes in sense and antisense orientation side by side.
5. Use the wt parental cell line as control.
6. Perform qPCR with primers in exons adjacent to the gene trap vector or western blot to confirm loss of function.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I aimed to establish a protocol to generate patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines using peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs), which is a less invasive source compared to somatic cells. This approach involved isolating PBMCs from patients with specific diseases, in this case, from patients diagnosed with Dent I disease, and reprogramming them into iPSCs via electroporation. My objective was to develop a reliable, efficient method for iPSC derivation that could be used for disease modeling and potential future therapeutic applications. Additionally, I was interested in exploring an alternative feeder approach using Geltrex or Matrigel matrix to replace mouse embryonic fibroblast (MEF) feeder layers, potentially simplifying the reprogramming process and reducing the risk of unknown outcomes associated with MEF feeders.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. RPMI 1640
2. FBS
3. Penicillin-Streptomycin
4. DMSO
5. DMEM-high glucose
6. StemSpan™-XF
7. StemSpan™-CC100
8. HoCT3/4
9. Hsk sox2 KLF4
10. L-myc LIN28
11. 4D-Nucleofector™ X Unit (V4XP-3012)
12. PBMCs
13. plasmid DNA
14. P3 Primary Cell 4D-Nucleofector™ X Solution
15. Program EO-015
answer:
1. Collect 2–4 mL of human venous blood in heparinized vials.
2. Dilute the sample with an equal volume of D-PBS and transfer to a new 15 mL tube by gently mixing 2-5 times by inversion.
3. Isolate PBMCs using the Solarbio P8610 gradient centrifugation technique, adding an appropriate amount of separation solution to the centrifuge tube.
4. Gently layer the diluted blood on top of the separation solution without mixing.
5. Centrifuge at 500–1000 g for 20–30 min at RT using a horizontal rotor.
6. Gently aspirate the lymphocyte layer using a plastic Pasteur pipette into a new 15 mL tube.
7. Wash the lymphocyte layer with 10 mL D-PBS by pipetting up and down 8–10 times.
8. Centrifuge at 250 g for 10 min at RT, remove supernatant, and repeat washing.
9. Resuspend the cell pellet in 500 μL D-PBS and count the cells using a hemocytometer.
10. Prepare cells at a density of 1–5 x 10^6 cells/mL for electroporation or freeze in cryopreservation solution.
11. Thaw PBMCs before electroporation and culture with PBMCs culture medium overnight.
12. Coat a 6-well plate with 1% (v/v) Matrigel, Geltrex matrix, or MEF-feeder.
13. Electroporate PBMCs using the Lonza 4D-Nucleofector™ with program EO-015.
14. Pre-incubate reprogramming medium at 37°C.
15. Prepare the DNA plasmid solution at 1 μg/μL in ddH2O.
16. Centrifuge PBMCs at 200 g for 10 min at RT and completely remove supernatant.
17. Resuspend cell pellet in 100 μL 4D Nucleofector™ Solution with DNA plasmids.
18. Transfer mixtures into Nucleocuvette™ Vessels and start program EO-015.
19. Incubate Nucleocuvette™ in a humidified incubator for 5 min post-electroporation.
20. Gently pipette to mix cells and seed onto the prepared 6-well plate.
21. After 4 h of incubation, collect cells and medium for centrifugation.
22. On day 3, replate cells into a new Geltrex or MEF-feeder coated 6-well plate.
23. Add 200 μL mTeSR™1 per well on day 4.
24. Perform medium changes on days 6, 8, and 10, centrifuging and replating cells.
25. On day 11, switch to complete mTeSR™1 medium daily changes until day 25.
26. Monitor cells for iPSC colony formation from day 12–25.
27. Select iPSC clones for amplification when colony boundaries become blurred.
28. Under a microscope, remove most of the medium leaving about 100-200 μL.
29. Break colonies into fragments and transfer to a 96-well plate coated with Geltrex or Matrigel matrix.
30. Culture with mTeSR™1 and 10 μM Y-27632 at 37°C in 5% CO2 incubator.
31. Replace medium after 24 h with mTeSR™1 without Y-27632.
32. Change culture medium daily with fresh mTeSR™1.
33. Passage cells at 70% confluence and gradually amplify into larger well plates.
34. Perform functional verification tests when enough cells are obtained (minimum six 6-well plates).

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I aimed to understand the relationship between F-actin dynamics and membrane sculpting within the context of spermatid maturation and release in *Drosophila* testis. Specifically, I wanted to investigate the dynamics of F-actin structures during spermatid morphogenesis, including individualization, coiling, and release of spermatids, using high-resolution, time-lapse imaging. My objective was to capture these processes *ex vivo* with minimal photo-toxic damage, to study the subcellular changes and correlate them with morphogenetic processes under different genetic backgrounds and specific drug treatments. This would allow for a deeper insight into actin and plasma membrane remodeling and their interplay in cellular processes, leveraging the *Drosophila* testis as a model system due to its simplicity and relevance.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
2. Olympus FLUOVIEW FV1000 confocal microscope
3. FV3000 confocal microscope
4. IX71 microscope
5. IXPro series microscope
6. InGAsP-HSD photomultiplier-tube (PMT) detectors
7. Nikon Eclipse Ti2 inverted fluorescence microscope
8. Andor iXon 897 EMCCD camera
9. NIS elements software
answer:
1. Gently wipe the surface of the coverslip with lint-free tissue paper, and place the dish on clean tissue paper.
2. Add 50–80 μL poly-L-Lysine in the cavity, and leave undisturbed for 15–20 min.
3. Remove the poly-L-Lysine using a micropipette and give three quick washes using approximately 50 μL 1× PBS per wash to remove residual poly-L-Lysine.
4. Add fresh 1× PBS (80–100 μL) in the cavity, which will serve as the live imaging medium.
5. Set the light path for the relevant fluorophores according to the excitation and emission bands, set the frame size to 512×512 pixels, and make imaging mode simultaneous.
6. Depending on the type of experiment, set the required modalities.
7. Fill the dissection cavity with 1× PBS.
8. Anesthetize Drosophila males of relevant genotype using carbon dioxide or on a cold plate and transfer them onto the dissection cavity, using forceps.
9. Dissect out the testes from each fly as shown in the Methods video S2.
10. Gently pick up the dissected testes using a pair of forceps and place them on the surface of the coverslip of the petri dish containing the imaging medium.
11. Using the forceps, gently adjust the inherent coiled shape of the testes, and ensure that it sticks to the poly-L-lysine coated surface.
12. Place multiple testes in a similar manner close to each other.
13. Soak a sheet of Whatman filter paper with PBS and place it at the side of the dish to maintain humidity in the chamber.
14. Seal the dish using Parafilm™ and place it on the microscope stage.
15. Identify the suitable samples using bright-field or DIC optics, which are appropriately mounted and appear intact, using a 10× objective.
16. Switch to the relevant higher objective according to the experimental requirement.
17. Using the wide-field epi-illumination for a quick scan of the specimen before starting the confocal imaging and locate the general region of interest (ROI) position within the testis.
18. Switch to the confocal mode of imaging and set the rest of the imaging parameters as detailed below.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
As someone deeply interested in improving the prognosis and treatment of glioblastoma (GBM), the most aggressive grade of glioma, I wanted to explore the potential of using molecular markers for the accurate diagnosis and classification of this cancer. The motivation for conducting this experiment comes from the necessity to find better diagnostic tools that can complement the current histology and imaging methods, given the poor prognosis associated with GBM. Specifically, I aimed to investigate if quiescent stem cell marker genes, within the context of glioma gene networks, can distinctly classify normal brain tissue from GBM samples. This exploration was driven by the cancer stem cell theory, which suggests that a minor stem cell population drives tumor growth and therapy resistance. Therefore, the purpose of this experiment was to identify these quiescent stem cell marker genes as potential diagnostic markers and therapeutic targets in GBM.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. RNA-seq gene expression data (fastq files, bam files, htseq-count files)
2. Microarray gene expression data
3. Windows computer
4. Linux computer
5. Mac computer
6. Internet connection
answer:
1. Analyze RNA-seq data from rat, mouse, and human using representative or sample code in Step1 RNAseqASUcyverseClusterResultsScript/; the starting files are fastq/bam files to produce htseq counts rest of the DEG, WGCNA, and MEGENA pipelines.
2. Conduct differential gene expression analysis comparing quiescence vs proliferation using approaches such as Limma, edgeR, and simple comparison of means starting from htseq count files obtained in Step 1 in DEGNoCuffQbyTStemCellspairs/.
3. Perform WGCNA analysis of htseq files obtained in Step 1, including GO analysis for characterization of modules, and apply Linear Regression/Modeling to distinguish control and cancer samples, followed by Survival analysis in HuDisGBsplitWGCNA/.
4. Execute MEGENA analysis of htseq files obtained in Step 1 and characterize modules with enrichR such as GO analysis in HuDisGBsplitMEGENA/.
5. Compare MEGENA analysis and WGCNA analysis outputs obtained in Step 3 and Step 4 for Preservation Analysis in Step5 PreservationAnalysis/.
6. Use RStudio to run the .Rmd codes provided in all steps, applying the 'knit to html' or 'Run all' command to reproduce the same results.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I've always been fascinated by traditional medicine and recently came across the practice of placentophagy, specifically in Chinese medicine, where the placenta is consumed for its purported health benefits. My motivation comes from a desire to understand traditional practices and their applications in modern integrative medicine. Therefore, I want to design an experiment to process human placenta tissue using methods that replicate those found in home-based preparations common within these traditions. The purpose of this experiment is to establish a protocol for preparing placenta tissue under clean, yet not sterile, conditions. This could bridge the gap between traditional and contemporary medicine practices, providing a basis for further research into the benefits and safety of placentophagy.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. eSwab containing Amies transport medium (Copan, Brescia, Italy)
2. disinfectant wipes Incidin™ OxyWipe S (Ecolab, Monheim am Rhein, Germany)
3. food processor (Moulinex DP800G, Frankfurt am Main, Germany)
4. food dehydrator (Stöckli Dörrgerät, Netstal, Switzerland)
5. steamer pot with water
6. stainless steal scissors/tweezers/scalpel
answer:
1. Measure weight/height/diameter of the placenta.
2. Exsize 5-10 g of placenta tissue for measuring the dry weight (dehydrated this piece at 100 °C for 8h).
3. Wash the placenta under cold running tab water.
4. Remove the umbilical cord.
5. Cut the placenta into three equal pieces.
6. Wrap the piece for steaming into the amnion.
7. Homogenize one-third of the placenta for analysis of raw tissue using the meat processor.
8. Bring water in the steamer pot to a boil.
9. Put the piece of placenta for steaming (on aluminum foil) into the steamer pot.
10. Steam for at least 10 minutes, check core temperature (the core temperature must reach 70 °C).
11. Continue steaming for another 5 minutes if the core temperature has not yet reached 70 °C.
12. Press the steamed piece of placenta after reaching the core temperature of 70 °C with a fork to see that the fluid coming out is clear: if not, resume steaming for another 5 minutes.
13. After finishing the steaming process, take the steamed piece out of the pot and let it cool on a clean metal plate.
14. Cut the pieces of placenta tissue (either raw or steamed) into 0.5 cm thin slices.
15. Place the slices on a baking foil in the dehydrator tray, make sure they do not overlap.
16. Start dehydration (8 hours at 55 °C).
17. Do the "snap test" after dehydration - if the tissue lost all its water content it will snap easily.
18. Continue dehydration for another hour if the tissue is not snap dry.
19. Clean the equipment after each preparation process with the Lab washing machine at 70 °C.
20. Wear gloves (non sterile) at every preparation step.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I wanted to explore how effectively animals, specifically rats, can navigate and remember their environment when searching for food. My motivation stems from a keen interest in understanding the cognitive abilities such as planning, working memory, and executive function involved in spatial navigation. The purpose of this experiment is to assess these cognitive abilities in nonhuman animals by utilizing the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP). This involves observing rats as they find the most efficient route to collect bait placed in varying positions within an arena. By analyzing their behavior in this setup, I aim to gather insights into their learning and memory capabilities, and how they plan their movements in a spatial context.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Rats
2. Ethanol
3. Semi-transparent purple vinyl index card dividers (Oxford Esselte, catalog number: 73153)
4. Rodent food dishes
5. Sterilized bottle caps
6. Froot Loops® cereal (or a generic equivalent)
7. Fruity Pebbles® or Cocoa pebbles®
8. Configuration Templates
9. Posterboard
10. Open Field Arena
11. Stopwatch
12. Video Camera
13. White Noise generator (e.g., HoMedics, model: SS-2000G/F-AMZ)
answer:
1. Begin handling the animals a minimum of 4 days prior to pre-training by picking up and holding each animal for a few minutes each day. If using novel food for bait, offer a few pieces of the cereal each day to acclimate the rats to the food.
2. Initiate food deprivation 2-3 days before pre-training by recording baseline weights, removing all food (but not water) for 24 hours, then providing limited food (about 40 g/rat) daily. Weigh rats each day and adjust food amount to maintain approximately 85-90% of baseline weight.
3. Conduct habituation on the first day of the experiment following 2-3 days of food deprivation. Dim lights to the lowest level compatible with video recording and turn on the white noise generator. Place animals individually into the arena to explore for 10 minutes, then return them to their home cage and feed. Ensure there are no distractions in the testing room and clean the arena between rats with an ethanol solution.
4. Begin pre-training after one day of habituation with environmental conditions identical to habituation. Run pre-training in stages:
   a. Stage one: Place four baited targets randomly in the arena; end trial after the rat retrieves all four pieces of bait or 10 minutes elapse. Complete this stage when the animal successfully retrieves all four pieces on two consecutive trials.
   b. Stage two: Use six baited targets; stage completion when the rat retrieves all six pieces on one trial.
   c. Stage three: Use eight baited targets; completion upon successful retrieval of all eight pieces on one trial.
   d. Stage four: Place 10 baited targets in the arena; complete pre-training when the animal successfully retrieves nine out of the 10 targets on three consecutive trials.
5. Move to the testing phase once pre-training is complete. Create a specific target configuration for the arena based on the test question. Record the rat's behavior for 10 minutes or until all bait is retrieved, place the rat back into the home cage, and feed. Sequence testing of different configurations should be balanced across rats.
6. After trials, code the video files for behavioral measures by assigning unique numbers to each target and determining the optimal route. Record contacts and retrievals, transitioning between targets, revisits, omissions, and span.
7. Analyze the videos using video-tracking software if actual travel distances are required. Calculate memory measures (revisits, omissions, span) and route choice measures (Percent Above Optimal, Proportion of Optimal Transitions, Proportion of Distance on Optimal).

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I need to analyze a large set of human immune cell samples from diverse clinical scenarios with high throughput and precision. My goal is to identify specific cell types and the expression of various proteins reliably. To minimize variations and inconsistencies between samples, which are common due to staggered staining times and instrument calibration changes, I plan to use mass cytometry, specifically CyTOF. I aim to multiplex these samples to streamline the process, conserve valuable reagents like antibodies, and reduce overall costs. By barcode-labeling the individual samples using metal-conjugated antibodies, I can combine them into one tube for staining and analysis. This approach will help to reduce batch effects and ensure consistency across all samples. Ultimately, this technique will offer a detailed phenotypic characterization of the immune cells, which is critical for understanding disease mechanisms and monitoring the effectiveness of treatments in clinical trials.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. FBS
2. PBS
3. Sodium azide
4. BSA
5. Cell-ID™ intercalator-Ir(500 μM)
6. 16% formaldehyde
7. 0.3% saponin
8. Fume hood
9. Personal protective equipment
answer:
1. Collect sample vials in a separate box for quick retrieval on the day of staining. Keep samples in liquid nitrogen storage until ready to begin the protocol.
2. Fill pre-labeled 15 mL tubes with 5 mL of pre-warmed thawing media. Prepare tubes, labels, buffers, and antibody mixtures.
3. Prepare antibody master mixes and store them at 4°C.
4. Prepare the barcode table, assigning each sample a CD45-Pt and one palladium code.
5. Prepare buffers and reagents, including CyTOF staining media (CSM), thawing media, and antibody master mixes according to provided dilutions and volumes.
6. Prepare the following buffers: 1× Maxpar perm barcode buffer, Fixation/permeabilization buffer, Fc blocker, Viability buffer, 1× Permeabilization buffer, and DNA staining buffer. Store and vortex before use.
7. Filter each antibody master mix using a 0.1 μm Millipore centrifuge tube and store the tubes at 4°C.
8. Thaw cells one at a time and quickly transfer the contents to the appropriate pre-labeled tube filled with thawing media. Leave it on ice, then centrifuge, aspirate supernatant, and if necessary, count and record viable cell counts. Resuspend cell pellets in thawing media again and transfer it to a 96-well V-bottom plate.
9. For viability stain and live-cell barcoding, prepare 103Rh viability buffer with CD45-194Pt or CD45-198Pt, add to samples, incubate, and then centrifuge to discard the supernatant.
10. For fixation and permeabilization, add fixation/permeabilization buffer to each well, incubate, add 1× Maxpar perm barcode buffer, centrifuge, and discard the supernatant.
11. Perform cell barcoding by adding prepared barcode buffer to each sample well according to the barcode map, incubate, add Maxpar CSM, centrifuge, and discard supernatant. Wash cells twice with Maxpar CSM.
12. For cell staining, perform Fc blocking, add 2× surface stain, incubate, wash with CSM and 1× permeabilization buffer. Perform intracellular staining with 1× intracellular stain, incubate, and then wash with PBS. Finally, label cellular DNA with DNA staining buffer, incubate, and wash with PBS.
13. Store stained cells in 200 μL of 1.6% FA/PBS for up to 1 week at 4°C.
14. Before acquisition, add PBS to stained and barcoded cells, centrifuge, aspirate the supernatant, and resuspend the cells in PBS. Count cells, filter using a 5 mL Round Bottom Polystyrene Test Tube with Cell Strainer Snap Cap, centrifuge, discard supernatant, and keep the tube containing the cell pellet on ice.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I'm working on a project that aims to better understand the processes related to aging and cancer initiation. My focus is on the accumulation of DNA damage and the activation of the DNA damage response. To achieve this, I need to effectively detect and analyze the phosphorylation of histone H2AX (γH2AX), a critical marker of DNA double-strand breaks and DNA damage response activation. This is vital because γH2AX highlights the regions of DNA damage across chromatin, providing a reliable measure of the cellular events following DNA insult. Therefore, my experiment is designed to develop and detail a protocol for the reliable detection of γH2AX in mammalian tissues preserved by formalin fixation and paraffin embedding, enabling me to mark and study the sites of DNA damage associated with the conditions of interest.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue sections cut at 2μm
2. Histolemon-Erba
3. EDTA 0.25mM pH8
4. H2O2 30%
5. TBS1X
6. BSA4%
7. Tween20 0.02%
8. γH2AX mouse
9. Anti-mouse DAKO Cytomation Envision+ System Labelled Polymer-HRP
10. DAKO Cytomation liquid DAB+ Substrate Chromogen System
11. Harris Hematoxylin
12. Eukitt
answer:
1. Deparaffinize tissue sections in Histolemon 2X10 min  
2. Hydrate tissue sections through graded alcohol series (100%,95%,70%, H2O) 1X5 min  
3. Incubate the slides in EDTA for 50 min at 95°C for antigen unmasking   
4. Cool the slides for 20 min at room temperature (RT), then wash once in H2O  
5. Incubate the slides in 3% H2O2 for 5 min at RT for quenching of endogenous peroxidases  
6. Wash twice in TBS 1X  
7. Preincubate the slides with Ab mix for 20 min at RT  
8. Incubate the slides ON at 4˚C with anti-γH2AX diluted in Ab mix at indicated concentration, then wash twice in TBS 1X  
9. Incubate the slides with secondary antibody for 30 min at RT, then wash twice in TBS 1X  
10. Incubate the slides in peroxidase substrate solution for 5 min at RT.   
11. Block the reaction in H2O, counterstain with Hematoxilin 15 sec and wash the slides in running H20  
12. Dehydrate tissue sections through graded alcohol series and mount with Eukitt  
13. Positive (irradiated skin) and negative (not irradiated skin) controls were included in each experiment

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I am interested in investigating the intricate cellular dynamics and interactions within the lymph node microenvironment, particularly in the context of non-Hodgkin lymphomas, which predominantly proliferate in this compartment. My motivation stems from a need to better understand the tumor heterogeneity and complex interplay between malignant and non-malignant cells within lymph nodes. The purpose of my experiment is to develop and optimize a gentle, time-efficient protocol for processing human lymph node samples. This protocol is designed to avoid enzymatic or mechanical stress that could alter cellular properties, making the samples suitable for delicate single-cell assays, such as single-cell RNA sequencing. This approach is crucial for preserving gene expression and epitope profiles, thereby enabling accurate analysis of lymphocyte heterogeneity and the effects of the tumor microenvironment on cell behavior.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. RPMI (1X)
2. Fetal bovine serum (FBS)
3. Penicillin 10,000 units/mL
4. Streptomycin 10 mg/mL
5. Phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) 1×
6. EDTA
7. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)
8. Binding buffer 20×
9. Water (sterile, distilled)
answer:
1. Transfer lymph node into a sterile mortar and add 5 mL cell culture medium.
2. Remove excessive fat and connective tissue using dissecting scissors or a scalpel.
3. Cut lymph node into small pieces of approx. 1–2 mm size using dissecting scissors and forceps.
4. Using a 5 mL serological pipette, thoroughly pipette up and down to gently wash out the lymphocytes.
5. Filter lymphocyte-containing medium through a 100 μm strainer into a sterile 50 mL tube.
6. Add 5 mL cell culture medium and repeat steps 3–5 once or twice depending on the size of the lymph node.
7. Rinse cell strainer with fresh cell culture medium to fill up the tube to 50 mL.
8. Centrifuge tube at 400 g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C.
9. Carefully decant supernatant.
10. Gently resuspend the pellet in 10 mL cell culture medium and pass cell suspension through 70 μm strainer.
11. Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C.
12. Resuspend cells in cell culture medium. In case of clumps, repeat steps 10–12.
13. Count cells and set 1 × 106 cells aside for quality control by flow cytometry.
14. Fill 2 mL cryotubes with 700 μL of cold freezing medium.
15. Dilute cell suspensions to desired cell concentration using cell culture medium, for instance 5 × 106 cells per 700 μL medium.
16. Add 700 μL cell suspension drop-wise to cryotubes and gently invert tubes a few times.
17. Place cryotubes quickly into a slow freezing container and store at −80°C for ≥ 24 h.
18. Transfer leftover 1 × 106 cells (from step 13) into a 5 mL flow cytometry tube.
19. Add 1 mL of washing buffer and centrifuge cells at 400 g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C.
20. Decant supernatant and resuspend pellet in remaining buffer (ideally 50–100 μL). Then, add the antibodies.
21. Briefly vortex and incubate at 4°C protected from light for 30 min.
22. Add 1 mL of washing buffer, centrifuge cells at 400 g for 5 min and discard supernatant.
23. Repeat for a total of three washes.
24. Resuspend cells in 200 μL washing buffer.
25. Put cells on ice and analyze them on a flow cytometer within 24 h.
26. Pre-warm water bath and EDTA-containing cell culture medium to 37°C.
27. Prepare 50 mL tubes with 10 mL of EDTA-containing cell culture medium.
28. Thaw frozen aliquots in pre-warmed water bath and quickly transfer cell suspension dropwise into the prepared tubes.
29. Centrifuge at 200 g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C and discard supernatant.
30. Resuspend cells in EDTA-free washing buffer.
31. Filter cell suspensions through 75 μm strainer.
32. Count cells, for instance manually by means of trypan blue and a hemocytometer.
33. Centrifuge at 200 g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C and discard supernatant.
34. To magnetically label the dead cells, resuspend the cell pellet in 100 μL magnetic beads per 1 × 107 cells. For fewer than 1 × 107 cells, use 100 μL.
35. Incubate for 15 min protected from light at 18°C–25°C.
36. Meanwhile, prepare magnetic Multistand, OctoMACS™ separator, and one MS columns per sample.
37. Wash each column with 500 μL 1X binding buffer and wait until the liquid has passed the column.
38. Place 15 mL tubes under each column to collect the flow-through.
39. Add 1 mL 1X binding buffer to each sample and apply each sample onto one column.
40. Wait until the liquid has passed the column before rinsing each column with 500 μL 1X binding buffer.
41. Perform a total of 4 washes in this way.
42. Centrifuge the collected flow-through at 200 g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C and discard supernatant.
43. Resuspend cells in washing buffer and handle them at 4°C.
44. Count cells and assess viability, for instance by means of trypan blue and a hemocytometer.
45. Continue with library preparation for single cell sequencing according to the manufacturer’s protocol.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I aim to develop a precise and efficient in vitro assay, named PASTA, to evaluate the selective inhibition of different PARP family enzymes by small-molecule inhibitors. My motivation stems from the recognition that while small-molecule PARP inhibitors are critical for understanding the biological roles of PARPs in cell biology, current methods do not test these inhibitors against the full spectrum of PARP enzymes. This gap in methodology inhibits our ability to confidently determine the specific effects of single PARP inhibitors on cellular processes. Therefore, I need a protocol that allows for the semi high-throughput screening of PARP inhibitors, providing a straightforward, one-day experimental process that yields easily quantifiable data. This will enhance our understanding of PARP biology and the development of more selective PARP-targeting therapies.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Multichannel pipet
2. Reagent reservoirs
3. Plate reader
4. PARP buffer for ribosylation reaction (PBR)
5. HEPES, pH 7.5
6. NaCl
7. MgCl2
8. TCEP
9. ddH2O
10. TBTA
11. CuSO4
12. Biotin-N3
13. PBS
14. BSA
15. Strep-HRP
16. Plasmids for bacterial PARP expression
17. 6-alkyne-NAD+
answer:
1. Prepare a 1 μM solution of the target protein in PBR.
2. Add 50 μL of the target protein solution to a Ni-NTA coated 96-well plate and incubate at room temperature (RT) for 1 h.
3. Prepare a 4× solution of 6-alkyne-NAD+ at 0.4 mM.
4. Prepare 4× solutions of inhibitors from 800× DMSO stocks by adding 1 μL of the DMSO stock to 199 μL PBR.
5. Prepare a 2× compound/6-alkyne-NAD+ solution by combining equal volumes of each 4× compound dilution and 4× 6-alkyne-NAD+ solution.
6. Prepare a 2× solution of the PARP at 20 nM.
7. Remove the target protein solution and wash plate 3× with 100 μL 1× PBST, 1× with 100 μL 1× PBS, and 1× with 100 μL PBR, leaving each wash for ≥2 min at RT.
8. Add 25 μL of 2× PARP solution to the 96-well plate followed by 25 μL of 2× compound/6-alkyne-NAD+.
9. Incubate the plate at 30°C for 1 h.
10. Remove the enzymatic reaction solution and wash the plate 3× with 100 μL 1× PBST and 1× with 100 μL 1× PBS, leaving each wash for ≥2 min at RT.
11. Add 50 μL click reaction solution (100 μM TBTA, 1 mM CuSO4, 100 μM biotin-N3, 2 mM TCEP, 1× PBS) to the 96-well plate.
12. Incubate at 30°C for 30 min.
13. Remove the click reaction solution and wash the plate 3× with 100 μL 1× PBST and 1× with 100 μL 1× PBS, leaving each wash for ≥2 min at RT.
14. Add 50 μL 1% milk in PBST to the 96-well plate.
15. Incubate at RT for 30 min.
16. Remove the milk block and wash the plate 3× with 100 μL 1× PBST and 1× with 100 μL 1× PBS, leaving each wash for ≥2 min at RT.
17. Add 50 μL Strep-HRP (300 ng/μL BSA, 0.5 ng/μL Strep-HRP, 1× PBS).
18. Incubate at RT for 15–30 min.
19. Remove the Strep-HRP and wash the plate 3× with 100 μL 1× PBST and 1× with 100 μL 1× PBS, leaving each wash for ≥2 min at RT.
20. Prepare the QuantaRed solution per the instructions in the kit.
21. Add 100 μL QuantaRed solution to each well and incubate for 30 s to 1 min then quench with the QuantaRed stop solution.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I'm interested in understanding the variations in gene expression profiles across different types of cancer. Specifically, I want to evaluate the consistent patterns or anomalies that might indicate potential biomarkers or therapeutic targets. My motivation is to contribute to personalized medicine by identifying genes that play a key role in cancer progression or response to treatment. For this purpose, I plan to reprocess RNA-sequencing data from the publicly-available Pan-Cancer analysis project provided by The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), aiming for normalized and comparable expression results. This will involve using linear modeling and normalization to ensure the data are interpreted correctly and can be compared across samples. Ultimately, I hope to highlight significant genes, such as CYP3A5, PXR, and NR1I2, that could be crucial in cancer research and treatment strategies.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. RNA-Seq data from TCGA PanCan
2. tcga_RSEM_Hugo_norm_count.gz
3. Metadata file
4. metadata.csv
5. R/Rstudio (Version 3.5.2 or higher)
6. edgeR package
7. limma package
8. forcats package
9. ggplot2 package
10. Computer with requisite software and packages
answer:
1. Load necessary packages:
   - library(edgeR)
   - library(limma)
   - library(forcats)
   - library(ggplot2)
   - library(readr)

2. Import the files:
   - Set the RStudio working directory to the location of the gene counts and metadata files.
   - Import the gene counts file using read_delim.
   - Import the metadata file using read_csv and view it with View(metadata).

3. Prepare counts dataframe:
   - Make a dataframe of the counts as.data.frame.
   - Set the rownames equal to the first column and then delete the first column.
   - Back-transform the data from Log2(counts+1) to 'counts'.
   - Check that the number of variables in the counts dataframe is equal to the number of observations in the metadata.

4. Perform TMM normalization and Voom transformation:
   - Create DGEList from counts dataframe.
   - Perform filtering with rowSums and cpm.
   - Define group factor from metadata.
   - Create design matrix with model.matrix.
   - Calculate normalization factors with calcNormFactors.
   - Perform voom transformation with voom.
   - Fit linear model with lmFit.

5. Generate results as Log2(Normalized CPM+1):
   - Generate the normalized CPM.
   - Add pseudocount of +1.
   - Transform to Log2 scale and convert to a dataframe.

6. Export the results:
   - Export the Log2-normalized CPM+1 results with write.csv.

7. Obtain normalized expression of a single gene of interest across all cohorts:
   - Extract expression data for the gene of interest, CYP3A5.

8. Transpose and reformat to obtain a final dataframe having Sample ID, Expression, and Cohort:
   - Transpose the gene-specific dataframe.
   - Add row names as a column to the dataframe.
   - Rename the column corresponding to gene expression.

9. Merge the expression dataframe with metadata:
   - Merge expression data with metadata using merge.

10. Change the expression values to numeric instead of a factor:
    - Convert expression factor to numeric with as.numeric and levels.
    - Rebind the dataframe and rename the column for expression.

11. Export the expression results of single gene across all cohorts:
    - Export the merged, gene-specific dataframe with write.csv.

12. Plot the results ranked by median expression:
    - Generate a boxplot with ggplot, using geom_boxplot, theme, geom_point, theme_bw, and coord_flip.
    - Set x-axis labels with xlab and reorder them by median expression using fct_reorder.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I'm focusing on understanding and managing chronic pain, a condition that distresses a significant portion of the global population. My goal is to explore the pathophysiological mechanisms behind chronic pain and identify potential new analgesic treatments. Given the challenges associated with evaluating pain sensitivity in rodent models, I'm particularly interested in finding a reliable method to assess static mechanical pain hypersensitivity in rats. This led me to adopt the electronic von Frey test, an evolved and more user-friendly version of the manual approach for measuring pain sensitivity, enabling precise and efficient pharmacological research. My purpose is to leverage this method in different pain models, such as inflammatory and neuropathic pain, to gain insights that could translate into therapeutic advances for chronic pain management.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
Materials and Reagents

1. Plastic tip (Harvard Apparatus, catalog number: 76-0488)
2. Rats
3. Cleaning solution
4. Oxaliplatin (6 mg/kg, dissolved in 5% glucose)

Equipment

1. Apparatus (Harvard Apparatus, catalog number: 76-0886/87)
2. Electronic von Frey test (BIO-EVF4, Bioseb®, France)
answer:
1. Transport rats to the experimental room and allow them to acclimate for at least 1 h in their home cages.
2. Place rats on the apparatus for 30 min for habituation; this is done over two days.
3. Secure the boxes with a heavy object to prevent escapes.
4. Between each batch, clean the boxes with water humidified paper.
5. On the testing day, transport rats to the experimental room 1 h before testing and place the first batch on the boxes for 15 min.
6. Attach a clean plastic tip to the probe and zero the read-out.
7. Apply the tip of the force transducer on the middle of the rat hind paw and increase the pressure gradually until a clear withdrawal of the paw is observed.
8. Record the pressure value that elicited the withdrawal response.
9. Perform the test on the adjacent rat and repeat the measurements until two close withdrawal thresholds are observed with at least 3-5 min apart between stimulations on the same paw.
10. If needed, test both hind paws or use the contralateral limb as an intra-animal control in cases of mononeuropathy.
11. Ensure that the rats are immobile with their entire hind paw on the floor during the procedure.
12. Disregard the first measurement if the rat reacts prematurely and take a minimum of 3 measurements for each paw.
13. Apply the tip perpendicularly to the hind paw at a consistent speed across all trials to reduce variability.
14. If rats become unresponsive over time, gently tap or run a pen along the wire grid to increase attention before testing.
15. Habituate animals to handling by gently holding them for a few seconds over a few days before starting the experiments if they have not been subjected to any other test.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I am interested in understanding the dynamics of DNA binding to a specific protein, which may have implications in the process of DNA repair. My aim is to establish a rapid and efficient experimental method to measure this interaction. The purpose of my experiment is to utilize fluorescence anisotropy to quantitatively analyze the equilibrium binding between DNA and the protein. I need this method to be faster than the existing ones so that I can process a large number of samples promptly while ensuring accuracy in the binding measurements. This will significantly aid in expediting my research on DNA-protein interactions and their role in the DNA repair mechanism.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
Reagents  
1) Purified protein at concentrations within a range from one-tenth to ten times the estimated Kd for binding to its target DNA sequence.  
2) Purified DNA, labeled with a fluorophore.  
3) Buffer that is physiologically relevant for the protein.  

Equipment  
1) Fluorescence plate reader with polarization capabilities.  
2) Appropriate software for calculating anisotropy from polarization data.  
3) Microtiter plate appropriate for the instrument and measurement.
answer:
1. Measure the fluorescein-labeled DNA for its DNA concentration and fluorescein stoichiometry.
2. Incubate protein-DNA complexes at ambient temperature for 30 minutes prior to measurements.
3. Measure anisotropy using a fluorescent plate reader and determine G-factor adjusted for polarization.
4. Perform all anisotropy measurements in triplicate and with proteins from different purification batches.
5. Add purified proteins at increasing concentrations with a constant concentration of fluorescein-labeled DNA and fit binding curves to a single-ligand binding model to determine Kd.
6. Form a complex of MSH2MSH3 and fluorescein-labeled (CA)4-loop DNA and add increasing concentrations of unlabeled homoduplex DNA. Incubate at ambient temperature for 60 minutes.
7. Plot change in anisotropy versus concentration of added homoduplex DNA and fit to a 3-parameter hyperbolic decay curve to calculate Ki.
8. For unimolecular dissociation rate constant measurement, add a competitor ligand at time 0. Program the instrument to read in kinetic mode at specified intervals and fit to the first order decay equation or calculate from the half-life.
9. Ensure thorough mixing of reaction components for homogenous reactions.
10. Verify the labeling ratio of DNA and fluorescein is stoichiometric for optimal sensitivity.
11. Use sterile buffers and maintain a protease-free laboratory environment for homogeneous reagents.
12. Equilibrate protein in assay buffer prior to experiment using desalting spin-columns for rapid buffer exchange.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
In light of the global COVID-19 pandemic, extensive measures have been put in place to safeguard healthcare professionals and the public. Among these, wearing medical masks for extended periods has been emphasized as a key preventive measure. As a healthcare worker myself, I've grown increasingly concerned about the potential impact of prolonged mask usage on our natural nasal and oropharyngeal microbiome. Given the crucial role the microbiome plays in our health and well-being, I'm motivated to conduct a research study to explore any significant changes in these microbiomes caused by continuous mask use. The purpose of this experiment is to gather concrete data on how extended mask-wearing during the COVID-19 outbreak affects the nasal and oropharyngeal microbiome in healthy individuals, which could have important implications for healthcare protocols and guidelines.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Blood agar of Biomerieux ® (Lot No: 1007843450)
2. Macconkey Agar of Himedia ® (Lot No: 0000411827)
3. Swab sticks (sterile cotton with polypropylene stick in high density polyethylene (HPE) tube of Himedia ® (Code No: PW009))
4. Vitek-2 ® compact (Sensitivity machine)
answer:
1. Label the sample tube and fill the required requisition forms.
2. Put on the protective gown.
3. Wash your hands using either an alcohol-containing solution or soap and water.
4. Put on the gloves.
5. Put on the N95 or higher-grade mask.
6. Put on the face shield.
7. Request the individual to blow nose to get rid of excessive secretions.
8. Slightly tilt back the head of the patient to gain more access to the nasal passages and close the patient’s eyes.
9. Insert nasal swab just above the nasal passage floor, along the nasal septum, into the nasopharynx till resistance is felt.
10. Retain position of the swab for few seconds to absorb the secretions.
11. Take out the swab, rotating it, and put it into a collection tube.
12. Break the swab at the groove, discard the remains.
13. Close the tube, clean its surface with a wipe soaked in disinfectant, and put it into a biohazard bag.
14. Remove the gown and gloves.
15. Wash hands.
16. Wear a new pair of gloves, remove the face shield, and either discard or clean and store it.
17. Remove the gloves, rewash hands, wear a new pair of gloves and remove the face mask.
18. Take off the gloves and wash your hands.
19. Put on PPE and label the sample as described previously.
20. Swab the tonsilar pillars and posterior pharyngeal wall using a tongue depressor to hold the tongue.
21. Ask the individual to say “aah” to allow uvular elevation.
22. Put the swab into the pre-labeled viral transport media.
23. Wash slides in soap and water and wipe with an alcohol-based solution.
24. Label and mark a circular area on the underside of a clean glass slide.
25. Roll the swab over the clean slide surface to prepare a smear.
26. Air dry the smear and then heat fix by exposing to a Bunsen burner flame.
27. Stain the smear with crystal violet for 1 minute, rinse with water.
28. Add Gram’s iodine for 1 minute, rinse with water.
29. Decolorize with acetone or 95% ethyl alcohol for 5-10 seconds, rinse immediately.
30. Counterstain with safranin for 45 seconds, rinse, and blot dry.
31. View under a light microscope.
32. Choose isolate for growth and culture assessment.
33. Prepare microbial suspension and compare with McFarland Standard.
34. Make AST suspension using ID suspension.
35. Inoculate the cards within the Vitek-2 compact instrument.
36. Transfer cards from filling door to loading door manually for processing.
37. Scan cassette worksheet at the workstation.
38. Obtain the results within 5 to 8 hours.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I'm interested in pioneering new treatments for bone loss conditions, such as osteoporosis, by harnessing the potential of tissue engineering. Specifically, my goal is to investigate how mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs), seeded in hydroxyapatite (HA) scaffolds, can promote bone formation when transplanted into immunodeficient mice. The purpose of this experiment is to establish a reliable and efficient model for heterotopic bone formation using this combination of MSCs and HA scaffolds. By doing so, I aim to better understand the underlying mechanisms of bone regeneration and the role of various factors in this process, which could eventually lead to the development of novel regenerative therapies.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
### Materials and Reagents

1. Human or mouse mesenchymal stem cells
2. Mice [NOD.CB17-Prkdc/J mice]
3. Hydroxyapatite/tricalcium phosphate (HA/TCP)
4. 4% paraformaldehyde
5. Hematoxylin/Eosin (H&E) staining solution
6. Formic acid solution

### Equipment

1. 1 ml syringes
2. Cotton sticks
3. Scalpels
4. Racks
5. Tools for mouse surgery (scalpel, forceps, needle holder, scissors, sutures, sterile swabs, sterile drapes)
6. Scan microscopy
7. Computer
answer:
1. Take the 1 ml syringes, cut off the tips with a scalpel and let the syringe tip side open, but keep the piston inside as it is.
2. Weight 40 mg hydroxyapatite (HA/TCP) and transfer into each syringe.
3. Put a cut cotton stick to close the open side of the syringe.
4. Autoclave the syringes with hydroxyapatite (HA/TCP).
5. Take the sterilized syringes and HA/TCP back to cell culture room. Place syringes in a rack (syringes must be kept vertical).
6. Open the syringes, add 100 Î¼l 10% FBS MEM medium to each HA/TCP scaffold. Mix by 1 ml tip up and down pipetting to wet the HA/TCP thoroughly.
7. MSC cells (treated or transfected) are trypsinized and counted.
8. 5 x 105 cells in 200 Î¼l medium are transferred into HA/TCP in the syringe.
9. Mix thoroughly but gently by 1 ml tip up and down pipetting.
10. Place racks with syringes in the incubator, 37 Â°C, 5% CO2, overnight.
11. Next day, bring the transplant cells in the HA/TCP into the animal room. Ready for transplant cells subcutaneously in mice.
12. NOD/SCID mice, feed in sterilized animal room, around 8 weeks old. Each mouse can hold four implants in four positions (right-front, left-front, right-back, left-back).
13. Anaesthesia the mice using the general protocol. Let the mice lay relax with the back upside.
14. Shaving the fur of mice at middle of back, at one side of spine. Ethanol sterilizes the skin at the shaved area. Let it dry for a while.
15. Cut a 1-1.5 cm gap in the skin.
16. Push the piston of the syringe with cells inside, to get rid of the extra medium upper the implant.
17. Insert the 1 ml syringe with cells in HA/TCP into the cut gap in the skin. Go 1.5 cm forward under the skin to the front position from the cut gap to reach the front implantation position.
18. Push the piston of syringe and let the implant (HA/TCP with cells) out, settle implant at the position under the skin.
19. Slowly drag the syringe out, discard it.
20. Repeat the same step using another implant, this time let the syringe insert 1.5 cm back under the skin to the back position from the cut gap to reach the back implantation position.
21. After both front and back implants done, suture the cut over the skin.
22. Do the same on the other side of spine on the back of the mouse.
23. Continue till all the implants put into mice.
24. Keep the mice warm and under-watch in watch room overnight.
25. Then transfer mice into the regular feeding room (sterilized animal room).
26. Wait for 8 weeks till the bone formation in the implants.
27. Sacrifice the mice, take out each implant from each position, directly fix in 4% paraformaldehyde overnight.
28. Discard the paraformaldehyde, decalcified implant in formic acid for 3 days at 4 Â°C, then keep in PBS at 4 Â°C.
29. Embed the implants in paraffin using the general protocol.
30. Cut each implant into sections (4-Î¼m), at least three sections at different three positions of the implant.
31. Stain all the sections with H&E Y using the general protocol.
32. Take the section staining slides to the microscopy room.
33. Scan each section (the whole section) under microscopy.
34. Save the scanned pictures in disk.
35. Open each section scan picture in Photoshop or other image analysis software.
36. Pick all the red areas (bone tissue) in the section by proper tool, read out the size (pixels) of the whole red (pink) area. Then pick the whole section area, read out the size (pixels) of the whole implant section area.
37. Calculate bone formation ratio in each section as: Bone volume (Bv) = Red area size/Whole section size.
38. Do the same analysis for all the staining sections for each implant.
39. Put all the data together in the excel sheet, calculate the mean, standard variation, and perform proper statistic analysis to compare the difference between different groups.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I am interested in investigating the oxidative stress in 3-dimensional reconstructed human tissues grown at the air-liquid interface since oxidative stress is implicated in several diseases. My goal is to accurately measure the ratio of reduced glutathione (GSH) to oxidized glutathione (GSSG) in these tissues as an indicator of oxidative stress. Using Promega’s GSH/GSSG-Glo™ Assay, I aim to determine both GSH and GSSG levels with a single tissue sample, making the process more cost-effective and efficient. My objective is to optimize the lysis method for obtaining accurate oxidative stress assessments without the need to double the number of tissue samples, hence saving resources while still acquiring comprehensive data on the tissue’s oxidative state.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
## Reagents

1. 5% Sulfosalicylic Acid (SSA)

2. 500 mM HEPES, pH 8 (Neutralization buffer)

3. 250 mM HEPES, pH 7.5 (Dilution buffer)

4. GSH/GSSG-Glo™ Assay Kit (Promega, Catalog no. V6611 or V6612)

5. Cell scrapers

6. Microcentrifuge tubes

7. Opaque, white, 96-well plates

## Equipment

1. Luminometer

2. Ultrasonic bath

3. Refrigerated centrifuge with a rotor for microcentrifuge tubes
answer:
1. Add 100 µL of cold 5% SSA to the apical surface of the tissue and wait for approximately 5 minutes to allow the proteins to precipitate.
2. Scrape the tissue using a cell scraper and transfer the resulting suspension to a microcentrifuge tube.
3. Sonicate the sample tubes for 5 to 10 minutes in an ultrasonic ice-cold water bath.
4. Centrifuge the sample tubes for 10 minutes at 14000 × g and 4 °C.
5. Collect and aliquot the supernatants as needed. Use the samples in the GSH/GSSG assay or store them at ≤ -80 °C for later use.
6. If using frozen samples, thaw the samples on ice or at 2 to 8 °C.
7. Neutralize the samples with an equal volume of cold neutralization buffer.
8. If necessary, dilute the samples further with a cold dilution buffer.
9. Prepare the GSH standards by serially diluting the glutathione stock in a buffer containing 5% SSA, neutralization buffer, and/or dilution buffer.
10. Load the samples (25 µL) and GSH standards (25 µL) on an opaque white 96-well plate.
11. Add 25 µL of either Total Glutathione Lysis Reagent or Oxidized Glutathione Lysis Reagent to appropriate wells designated for tGSH or GSSG determination, respectively.
12. Shake for 5 to 10 minutes on a plate shaker.
13. Add 50 µL of Luciferin Generation Reagent to all wells and incubate at room temperature for 30 minutes.
14. Add 100 µL of Luciferin Detection Reagent to all wells and incubate at room temperature for 30 minutes.
15. Measure luminescence using a Luminometer, and calculate GSH/GSSG ratio mathematically.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I'm interested in understanding the mechanism of gene function on a molecular level. Specifically, I want to explore the effects of overexpressing the MG53 gene in different cell types, namely HEK293T and C2C12 cells. My motivation stems from previous studies suggesting MG53 plays a critical role in cellular processes, and I aim to leverage its overexpression as a model to further dissect its biological functions. This experiment will allow for the efficient expression of MG53 in these cells, enabling the subsequent analysis of its impact on cellular functions in vitro. Through this, I hope to gain insights into the gene's role and potentially uncover new therapeutic targets or strategies related to the mechanisms it influences.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. β-actin antibody
2. MG53 antibody
3. Adenovirus expressing: β-gal
4. Adenovirus expressing: Myc-MG53
5. Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium
6. Fetal bovine serum
7. Donor Equine Serum
8. Trypsin
9. 1×PBS
10. Lipofectamine™ 3000 Transfection Reagent
11. HEK293T cells
12. C2C12 cells
13. Plasmid: Myc-MG53
14. Plasmid: Flag-MG53
15. Image Lab software
16. GraphPad Prism 6 software
17. CO2 incubator
18. P3000™ Reagent
answer:
1. Seed 4.5 × 10^5 - 6.0 × 10^5 cells per 3.5 cm dish (or one well of a 6-well plate) in 2 mL of complete growth medium. Incubate cells overnight at 37°C in 5% CO2 incubator.
2. Transfect cells with 1 μg Myc-MG53 plasmid using 2 μL P3000™ Reagent and 3 μL Lipofectamine™ 3000 Reagent per 3.5 cm dish according to the manufacturer’s instructions. After transfection for 6 h, switch to fresh culture medium.
3. Harvest cells 24–36 h after transfection for further experimentation such as co-immunoprecipitation or Western blotting.
4. Seed myoblasts in dishes to reach 70%–80% confluence.
5. Replace complete growth medium with differentiation medium (DMEM with 2% donor equine serum) and add adenovirus into the medium. Swirl briefly to distribute the virus uniformly in the dish.
6. Change medium (fresh differentiation medium) 24 h after infection.
7. Culture infected myoblast cells in differentiation medium for at least 4 days to induce differentiation into myotubes.
8. Change differentiation medium every 2 days during the differentiation period.
9. Harvest cells after differentiation for at least 4 days.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
I aim to develop a reliable and efficient method to quantify endosomal recycling of the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor (EGFR) in breast cancer cells, particularly focusing on the BT-549 cell line. Traditional methods for studying receptor recycling have limitations such as the requirement for radioactive materials, the need for large cell quantities, or procedures that could affect the integrity of the cells. Therefore, my goal is to establish a protocol that utilizes immunofluorescence to assess EGFR endosomal recycling accurately while avoiding these limitations. Specifically, I want to ensure this method uses fewer cells, is less time-consuming, and is safer than radioactive techniques. The purpose is to compare the differences in EGFR recycling between wild-type PKCδ and a mutant form, Y374F-PKCδ, potentially unveiling molecular mechanisms underlying this process in breast cancer pathophysiology.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. RPMI 1640 1×
2. FBS
3. EGF (2 μg/mL)
4. Ab3 (200 μg/mL)
5. Tris
6. NaCl
7. ddH2O
8. KCl
9. Na2HPO4
10. KH2PO4
11. Triton X-100
12. BSA
13. Formaldehyde solution (37%)
14. HCl (1 M)
15. PPE (Personal Protective Equipment)
16. Eppendorf P1000
answer:
1. For culture of adherent cells precoat Lab-tek chamber slides with fibronectin (0.1 mg/mL) by adding 200 μL per well and then incubate for minimum 15 min at 37°C.
2. Aspirate fibronectin and seed cells at 20,000 cells per well into RPMI supplemented with 10% FBS and 0.023 IU/mL insulin.
3. After 48 h, replace medium with low serum medium (RPMI/0.1% FBS) to starve cells for 20 h.
4. On ice prepare master mix for labeling cell surface presented EGFR, volumes below are enough for 6 chamber slides using 8 well/chamber slide.
5. Place cells on ice, aspirate medium and replace with 200 μL of cell surface labeling solution per well.
6. Label baseline cell surface receptors by incubating chamber slides with cell surface labeling solution at 4°C for 60 min with gentle rocking on rocking platform mixer.
7. Following surface labeling, place all chamber slides on ice.
8. For the remaining chamber slides, while still on ice, aspirate cell surface labeling solution and replace with pre-warmed trafficking solution.
9. Perform an endocytosis pulse by incubating cells at 37°C for 15 min.
10. Following the pulse, place all chamber slides on ice.
11. On ice, aspirate trafficking solution and add cold acid strip solution and incubate with gentle rocking for 5 min.
12. Aspirate acid strip solution and wash gently ×4 with cold trafficking solution.
13. For the remaining chamber slide, while still on ice, aspirate cold trafficking solution and replace with prewarmed trafficking solution to allow recycling.
14. Perform receptor recycling by incubating cells at 37°C for 30 min.
15. After the 30 min recycling time, fix cells with fixation solution for 5 min on ice followed by 10 min at room temperature (21°C–25°C).
16. Following fixation wash ×2 with PBS (1×) then store at 4°C covered with PBS (1×) until processing.
17. Aspirate PBS and wash cells ×3 in wash buffer.
18. Add 200 μL block solution per well and incubate at room temperature (21°C–25°C) for 60 min.
19. Aspirate block solution and add 200 μL of secondary antibody solution diluted in appropriate block solution) and incubate in the dark at room temperature (21°C–25°C) for 60 min with gentle rocking.
20. Wash cells ×3 in wash buffer then mount using ProLong Gold Antifade Mountant with DAPI.

question:
Below is a user's experimental design requirement:
As a researcher interested in the field of molecular biology and disease diagnosis, I've noticed the increasing importance of exosomal RNA in understanding disease mechanisms and biomarker discovery. My objective is to isolate total extracellular RNA from serum or plasma effectively and reproducibly. This is crucial for my experiments aiming at biomarker identification in various diseases. To achieve this, I'm seeking an optimized and reliable protocol that can handle larger biofluid volumes for extraction, ensuring consistency and efficiency in RNA yield. This led me to adapt and evaluate an updated version of an existing protocol, using the Qiagen miRNeasy Micro kit, which promises better reproducibility and efficiency by processing increased volumes of serum or plasma compared to previous methods.
Give the materials, reagents, and equipment that may be required for the experiment, please design a detailed and step-by-step procedure for the experiment based on the user's needs:
1. Qiagen miRNeasy micro kit (217084)  
2. Chloroform (Sigma-Aldrich – 319988)  
3. 100% ethanol (Koptec – V1016)  
4. 70% ethanol  
5. RNase-free water (Ambion – AM9937)  
6. Refrigerated microfuge or tabletop centrifuge  
7. 15 mL Centrifuge tubes  
8. 1.5 mL Microfuge tubes  
9. Vortexer  
10. Phase lock gel tubes (PLG), 2 mL (VWR – 10847-802)
answer:
1. Transfer 500 µL of biofluid into a 15 mL centrifuge tube.
2. Add 2500 µL (5x volumes) of QIAzol Lysis Reagent.
3. Vortex 5 sec.
4. Incubate for 5 min at room temperature.
5. Add 500 µL chloroform.
6. Shake vigorously for 15 seconds.
7. Incubate for 3 minutes at room temperature.
8. Centrifuge sample for 15 min at 12,000 x g at 4°C.
9. Transfer the upper aqueous phase to a new 15 mL centrifuge tube. Avoid the white interphase.
10. Carefully measure the aqueous phase and add 1.5 x volumes of 100% ethanol.
11. Mix gently and thoroughly.
12. Assemble a MinElute spin column in a new collection tube.
13. Load up to 700 µL of the mixture from step 11 onto the column.
14. Spin for 15 seconds at 1,000 x g at room temperature.
15. Discard flow-through and repeat steps 13-14 until the entire sample has been loaded.
16. Add 700 μL Buffer RWT to the RNeasy MinElute spin column.
17. Centrifuge for 15 seconds at 8000 x g at room temperature to wash the column.
18. Discard the flow-through.
19. Pipet 500 μL Buffer RPE onto the RNeasy MinElute spin column.
20. Centrifuge for 15 seconds at 8000 x g to wash the column.
21. Discard the flow-through.
22. Pipet 500 μL 80% ethanol onto the RNeasy MinElute spin column.
23. Centrifuge for 2 minutes at ≥ 8000 x g at room temperature to wash the column.
24. Discard the collection tube with the flow-through.
25. Transfer the RNeasy MinElute spin column into a new 2 mL collection tube.
26. Open the lid of the spin column, and centrifuge at full speed for 5 min to dry the membrane.
27. Discard the collection tube with the flow-through.
28. Transfer the RNeasy MinElute spin column into a new 1.5 mL collection tube.
29. Add 14 or 30 μL RNase-free water directly to the center of the spin column membrane.
30. Centrifuge for 1 min at full speed to elute the RNA.
